questions.text: The most abundant glycoprotein in basement membrane is
questions.solution:
• Laminin is the most abundant glycoprotein in basement membrane Connects cells to underlying ECM components such as type IV collagen and heparan sulfate Can also modulate cell proliferation, differentiation, and motility.
  • Adhesive glycoproteins and adhesion receptors - Involved in cell-to-cell adhesion, linking cells to the ECM, and the interactions between ECM component.
  • Adhesive glycoproteins - fibronectin (a major component of the interstitial ECM) and laminin (a major constituent of basement membrane).
  • Adhesion receptors, also known as cell adhesion molecules (CAMs) - Integrins, immunoglobulins, cadherins, and selectins.
  • Fibronectin - Provide the scaffolding in healing wounds for subsequent ECM deposition, angiogenesis, and reepithelialization.
  • Integrins  essential for cells to attach to ECM constituents such as laminin and fibronectin Integrins on the surface of leukocytes are also essential in mediating firm adhesion and transmigration across endothelium at sites of inflammation and platelet aggregation.
  • Elastin  The ability of tissues to recoil and recover their shape after physical deformation is conferred by elastin.

questions.text: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are seen in
questions.solution:
• Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and fleurettes reflecting photoreceptor differentiation are seen in retinoblastomas.
  • Rosettes consist of a halo or spoke-wheel arrangement of cells surrounding a central core or hub.
Rosette type Morphology Tumour
Homer-Wright Central lumen or hub filled with fiber-like processes Medulloblastomas, PNET
Ependymal Empty-appearing lumen resembling a tubule Most well-differentiated ependymomas
Pseudorosette Spoke-wheel arrangement of cells with tapered cellular processes around a centrally placed vessel.  More sensitive for the diagnosis of ependymomas than true ependymal rosettes
Flexer-Wintersteiner Central lumen contains small cytoplasmic extensions of the encircling cells Retinoblastomas
Pineocytomatous Similar to the Homer Wright rosette, larger and more irregular in contour Pineocytomas

questions.text: A patient on long term hemodialysis due to renal failure is likely to develop which type of amyloidosis?
questions.solution:
Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis as a result of the deposition of β2-microglobulin.

β2-microglobulin is a component of the MHC class I molecule and a normal serum protein. In the past, it was retained in the circulation of patients with chronic kidney disease because it could not be filtered through dialysis membranes. In these patients, it would get deposited in the joints, muscles, tendons, and ligaments. One of the complications which can occur as a result is carpal tunnel syndrome. However, with the advent of new dialysis filters, this complication has become uncommon now.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.solution:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 
  • Hepatic cysts - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts 
  • Splenic cysts
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse 
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa results in
questions.solution:
Inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa results in Glanzman thrombasthenia

  • Autosomal recessive platelet surface receptor disorder of GPIIb/IIIa (ITG αIIbβ3), either qualitative or quantitative - Faulty platelet aggregation and diminished clot retraction.
  • Acquired GT is seen with platelet transfusions, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myelodysplastic syndrome, hairy cell leukemia, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
  • Normal platelet morphology and normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, absent or decreased clot retraction, and normal platelet aggregation in the presence of ristocetin.
  • Platelet aggregation is absent in the presence of epinephrine, collagen, arachidonic acid, ADP.
  • Under flow cytometric analysis, CD41 and CD61 levels are markedly decreased or absent

Classification of platelet disorders

Bernard Soulier Inherited deficiency ofIb-IX Decreased Increased Normal Normal
ITP Autoantibodies againstIIb-IIIa Decreased Increased Normal Normal
Glanzmann thrombasthenia Inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa Normal Increased Normal Normal

questions.text: A 20 year old previously healthy athlete suffers a sudden cardiac arrest while playing sport. On autopsy, there is massive myocardial hypertrophy. Microscopy shows myofiber disarray and interstitial fibrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy, poorly compliant left ventricular myocardium leading to abnormal diastolic filling, and intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction.
  • Leading cause of left ventricular hypertrophy unexplained by other clinical or pathologic causes.
  • Primarily diastolic dysfunction
  • Systolic function  usually preserved. 
  • Massive myocardial hypertrophy, usually without ventricular dilation
  • Septal hypertrophy

The most important histologic features of HCM myocardium are

  1. massive myocyte hypertrophy, with transverse myocyte diameters frequently greater than 40 μm (normal, approximately 15 μm)
  2. haphazard disarray of bundles of myocytes, individual myocytes, and contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells (termed myofiber disarray)
  3. interstitial and replacement fibrosis

One liners about HCM

  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Autosomal dominant
  • Most common mutation – Beta chain of myosin
  • Missense mutation
  • Subaortic hypertrophy and stenosis
  • Systolic function normal
  • Banana shaped left ventricle
  • Assymetric septal hypertrophy
  • Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet on Echo
  • Myofibre disarray on histology

questions.text: Which of the following tumour suppressor genes is an inhibitor of G1/S transition during cell cycle progression?
questions.solution:
RB, called the Governor of Proliferation is a key negative regulator of the G1 /S cell cycle transition and is directly or indirectly inactivated in most human cancers.

  • The normal RB gene is present on chromosome 13q14.
  • RB -  active hypophosphorylated state in quiescent cells and an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells passing through the G1/S cell cycle transition.
  • RB -  antiproliferative effects by binding and inhibiting E2F transcription factors that regulate genes required for cells to pass through the G1-S phase cell cycle checkpoint.
  • The antiproliferative effect of RB is abrogated in cancers through a variety of mechanisms, including:
    • Loss-of-function mutations affecting RB
    • Gene amplifications of CDK4 and cyclin D genes
    • Loss of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (p16/INK4a)
    • Viral oncoproteins that bind and inhibit RB (E7 protein of HPV)

Loss-of-function mutations of the RB gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, subset of glioblastomas, small-cell carcinomas of lung, breast cancers, and bladder carcinomas.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man underwent elective cholecystectomy. The cut specimen is seen below. The calculi observed is not associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pigmented gall stones and they are not associated with rapid weight reduction.

Pigment gallstones represent complex mixtures of insoluble and inorganic calcium salts with unconjugated bilirubin. Disorders with elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin increase the risk of developing pigmented gallstones. The various conditions associated with increase risk of pigmented gallstones are:

  • Demography: Asians more than Westerners, rural more than urban
  • Chronic hemolytic syndromes
  • Biliary infection with E.coli, Ascaris lumbricoides, and C. sinensis
  • Ileal disease
  • Ileal resection or bypass
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

Cholesterol gallstones are non-pigmented. Cholesterol is rendered soluble by bile by forming micelles with bile salts and lecithins. When cholesterol concentrations increase and surpass the solubilizing capacity of bile(supersaturation), it precipitates into solid cholesterol monohydrate crystals. The four mechanisms of cholesterol gallstone formation are:

  • Supersaturation of bile with cholesterol
  • Hypomobillity of the gallbladder
  • Accelerated cholesterol crystal nucleation
  • Hyper- secretion of mucus in the gallbladder

The conditions associated with an increased risk of development of cholesterol gallstones are:

  • Demography: Northern Europeans, North and South Americans, Native Americans, Mexican Americans
  • Advancing age
  • Female gender and sex hormones
  • Oral contraceptives
  • Pregnancy
  • Obesity and metabolic syndrome
  • Rapid weight reduction
  • Gallbladder stasis
  • Inborndisorders of bile acid metabolism
  • Hyperlipidemia syndromes

questions.text: The images below display the gross and microscopic features of a brain tumour in a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gross features (cystic tumor) and microscopy (microcystic and fibrillary areas) suggest pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytomas typically occur in children and young adults. It is located in the cerebellum, floor, and walls of the third ventricle, the optic nerves, and cerebral hemispheres. It is often cystic. Tumors are often biphasic, with both loose microcystic and fibrillary areas. Bipolar cells with long, thin “hairlike” processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork are seen.

Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are characteristic findings. Necrosis and brisk mitotic activity are uncommon.

questions.text: All the following familial tumour syndromes are associated with medulloblastoma except
questions.solution:
Cowden syndrome is associated with dysplastic gangliogliocytoma of the cerebellum caused by mutations in PTEN resulting in PI3K/AKT signaling pathway activity.

  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Medulloblastomas, caused by mutations in TP53
  • Turcot syndrome: Medulloblastoma or glioblastoma, caused by mutations in APC or mismatch repair genes
  • Gorlin syndrome: Medulloblastoma, caused by mutations in the PTCH gene resulting in up-regulation of sonic hedgehog signaling pathways.

questions.text: A 40 year old female presents with flaccid bullae over mucosa and skin and oral ulcers. Histopathology shows a suprabasal acatholytic blister with superficial dermal infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils. Direct immunofluresence for immunoglobulin IgG  is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Immunoflourescence shows deposition of immunoglobulin along the plasma membranes of keratinocytes in a reticular or fish net-like pattern accompanied by suprabasalar loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis). Flaccid bullae, oral ulcers,  suprabasal acantholytic blisters and fish net appearance on immunoflouresence are characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.

The majority of individuals who develop pemphigus are in the fourth to sixth decades.

Variants:

  1. pemphigus vulgaris
  2. pemphigus vegetans
  3. pemphigus foliaceus - IgG  is more superficial in pemphigus foliaceus
  4. pemphigus erythematosus
  5. paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Pemphigus vulgaris 
  • MC type of pemphigus
  • Involves the mucosa and skin
  • Oral ulcers that may persist for months before skin involvement appears.
  • Superficial flaccid vesicles and bullae that rupture easily
  • Pemphigus vulgaris - Autoantibodies against Dsg1 and Dsg3 - Blisters in the deep suprabasal epidermis
  • Pemphigus foliaceus - Autooantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.
  • Direct immunofluorescence - Net-like pattern of intercellular IgG deposits
  • A suprabasal acantholytic blister is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris
  • The single layer of intact basal cells -  row of tombstones appearance
  • Bullous pemphigoid autoantibodies bind BPAG2, a component of the hemidesmosomes, -à blister formation at the level of the lamina lucida of the basement membrane.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is caused by IgA autoantibodies to the fibrils that anchor hemidesmosomes to the dermis.

Classification of important bullous disorders

Disease Antigen Clinical features Histopathology DIF
Pemphigus vulgaris Desmoglein 1 and 3 Flaccid bullae, oral ulcers Suprabasal acatholysis IgG - Intercellular- Fish net pattern
Bullous pemphigoid BP 180 and 230 Tense bullae Subepidermal blister IgG and C3- Linear along the dermoepidermal junction
EBA Type VII collagen Tense bullae and erosions Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear
Dermatitis herpetiformis Tissue transglutaminase Grouped papules, vesiclea, urticarial plaques Subepidermal blister. Papillary microabscesses IgA at the tipsof dermal papillae

In the EBA, simplex type, defects of the basal cell layer of the epidermis almost always result from mutations in the genes encoding keratin 14 or keratin 5. In the junctional type -autosomal recessive defects in one of the subunits of laminin, a multicomponent protein located in the lamina lucida that binds to both hemidesmosomes and anchoring filaments , Mutations in BPAG2. Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa - Mutations in the COL7A1 gene, which encodes type VII collagen.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pyrogenic cytokine?
questions.solution:
IL-18 is not a pyrogenic cytokine.

Substances that induce fever are called pyrogens.

Exogenous pyrogens - Lipopolysaccharides of bacterial walls

Endogenous pyrogens - IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins

In the hypothalamus, the prostaglandins, especially PGE2, stimulate the production of neurotransmitters that reset the temperature set point at a higher level.

INF–α (early cytokine) has role fighting off viral infections.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is being evaluated for deafness and progressive mental decline. Physical examination reveals a child with short stature, coarse facial features,large tongue and cloudy cornea. Laboratory examination reveals increased urinary levels of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate. Metachromatic granules (Alder-Reilly bodies) are found in leukocytes from a bone marrow biopsy. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Hurler’s disease characterised by deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase.

Phenotypical features of Hurler's syndrome and Hunter's syndrome are quite similar, however Hunter syndrome do not show corneal clouding.

Features of Hurler's disease: 

  • Mental retardation
  • Coarse facial features
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Cloudy cornea
  • GAG's affected : Heparan sulfate and dermatan sulphate 

MPS

  • The MPSs are a group of closely related syndromes that result from genetically determined deficiencies of enzymes involved in the degradation of mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans).
  • All the MPSs except one are inherited as autosomal recessive traits; the exception, Hunter syndrome, is an X-linked recessive trait.
  • Mucopolysaccharides are abundant in the ground substance of connective tissue.
  • The glycosaminoglycans that accumulate in MPSs are dermatan sulfate, heparan sulfate, keratan sulfate, and chondroitin sulphate.
  • In the absence of enzymes involved in the degradation of these molecules -  Accumulation of partially degraded GAGs within lysosomes in multiple organs, including the liver, spleen, heart, and blood vessels.
  • The best described are Hurler syndrome(deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase) and Hunter syndrome(L-Iduronosulfate sulfatase)
  • Accumulations of GAGs within leukocytes produce Alder-Reilly bodies, while accumulations within neurons can produce zebra bodies.

Hurler’s syndrome

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Deficiency of α-L-Iduronidase
  • Characteristic appearance of patients - “gargoylism.”
  • Excrete excess dermatan sulfate and heparan sulphate in the urine

Hunter syndrome- Deficiency of L-Iduronosulfate sulfatase.

X linked recessive

I cell disease- Mucolipidosis  -  autosomal-recessive disorder

Deficiency of the enzyme UDP-N -acetylglucosamine: N -acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase. Accumulating metabolites- Cholesterol esters, triglycerides

Wolmans disease- Acid lipase deficiency

Accumulating metabolites- Cholesterol esters, triglycerides

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with fluctuating muscular weakness that worsens with exertion and often over the course of the day, diplopia and ptosis. The patient is also found to have an anterior mediastinal mass. What is the most likely tumour?
questions.solution:
The patient probably has myasthenia gravis. Approximately 15-20% of patients with myasthenia gravis have a thymoma, a tumor of thymic epithelial cells. Myasthenia gravis frequently involves ocular muscles, and is marked by fluctuating weakness that worsens with exertion.

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that is usually associated with autoantibodies directed against acetylcholine receptors.
  • Approximately 20% of patients with myasthenia gravis have a thymoma, a tumor of thymic epithelial cells.
  • An additional 60% of patients have thymic hyperplasia marked by the appearance of B-cell follicles in the thymus.
  • Thymoma - Tumors usually occur in adults older than 40 years of age.
  • Most arise in the anterior superior mediastinum.
  • WHO classification –  A , AB, B1, B2, B3, C

questions.text: All are signs of reversible cell injury except

choices.text: Blebbing and blunting of plasma membrane

questions.solution:
In irreversible cell injury or cell death, the basophilia of the nuclear chromatin may fade called karyolysis, a change that presumably reflects loss of DNA because of enzymatic degradation by endonucleases.

CELL INJURY

  • Within limits, a cell can repair derangements and, if the injurious stimulus abates, will return to normalcy.  This is called reversible cell injury.
  • Persistent or excessive injury, however, causes cells to pass the rather nebulous “point of no return” into irreversible injury and cell death.

The ultrastructural changes of reversible cell injury include:

  • Plasma membrane alterations, such as blebbing, blunting, and loss of microvilli
  • Mitochondria - swelling and the appearance of small amorphous densities
  • Dilation of the ER, with detachment of polysomes
  • Intracytoplasmic myelin figures
  • Nuclear alterations -  disaggregation of granular and fibrillar elements

Irreversible cell injury

  • Increased eosinophilia , glassy homogeneous appearance
  • Whorled phospholipid masses called myelin figures derived from damaged cell membranes
  • Discontinuities in plasma and organelle membranes
  • Marked dilation of mitochondria with the appearance of large amorphous densities
  • Intracytoplsmic amorphous debris, and aggregates of fluffy material probably representing denatured protein.
  • Nuclear changes - karyolysis, pyknosis and karyorrhexis

questions.text: A transplant recipient with pneumonitis progresses to full-blown acute respiratory distress syndrome. Lung biopsy reveals an interstitial mononuclear infiltrate with foci of necrosis accompanied by the typical enlarged cells with inclusions as shown below. Most likely organism is
questions.solution:
Lung biopsy shows congestion and distinct nuclear and ill-defined cytoplasmic Inclusions of CMV.

Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., transplant recipients, HIV infected individuals) are susceptible to severe CMV infection.

  • Recipients of solid-organ transplants (heart, liver, kidney) contract CMV from the donor organ.
  • Life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections in immunosuppressed people primarily affect the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis).
  • In the pulmonary infection an interstitial mononuclear infiltrate with foci of necrosis develops, accompanied by the typical enlarged cells with inclusions.
  • The pneumonitis can progress to full-blown acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • Diagnosis of CMV infections is made by demonstration of characteristic  morphologic alterations in tissue sections, viral culture, rising antiviral antibody titer, detection of CMV antigens.

questions.text: All of the following statements about hairy cell leukemia are true except

choices.text: Most common T cell lymphoid neoplasm
Shows activating point mutations in the serine/threonine kinase BRAF

questions.solution:
Hairy cell leukemia is a rare but distinctive B-cell neoplasm

  • Hairy cell leukemias -  90% of cases with activating point mutations in the serine/threonine kinase BRAF.
  • Massive splenomegaly and pancytopenia.
  • Leukemic cells have fine hairlike projections that are best recognized under the phase-contrast microscope
  • Dry tap on aspirate
  • Express the pan-B-cell markers CD19 , CD11c, CD25, CD103, and annexin A1
  • Increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections, possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia.

questions.text: Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are called:
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumors containing nests of neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium surrounded by abundant dense, fibrous stroma are Brenner tumors or transitional cell tumors.

Transitional cell tumors are a rare type of ovarian epithelial tumor. They contain neoplastic epithelial cells resembling urothelium and are usually benign. They are often detected incidentally and even when large they do not produce any symptoms.

Microscopy features include fibrous stroma, with sharply demarcated nests of urothelial cells, often with mucinous glands in their center, called Walthard cell rests, as seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option B- Krukenberg tumor is a bilateral metastatic ovarian malignancy with the primary site in the gastrointestinal tract. Microscopically, it is characterized by the appearance of mucin-secreting signet-ring cells in the tissue of the ovary.

Option C- Sertoli cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor that commonly produces masculinization or defeminization. These tumors showed a range of  differentiation:

 - Well-differentiated tumors show tubules composed of Sertoli cells or Leydig cells interspersed with stroma
 - Intermediate forms show immature tubules with large eosinophilic Leydig cell
 - Poorly differentiated show sarcomatous pattern

Option D- Hilus cell tumors or pure Leydig cell tumors are also sex cord-stromal tumors. They are rare and unilateral tumors. Large lipid-laden Leydig cells with distinct borders and characteristic rod-shaped cytoplasmic structures called Reinke crystalloids are present in these tumors. Females with hilus cell tumors usually have features of masculinization.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient is found on rectal examination to have a hard, irregular nodule within his prostate. A biopsy of this lesion reveals the presence of crowded small glands lined by a single layer of cells with enlarged, prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemistry shows the absence of the outer basal cell layer. From what portion of the prostate did this lesion most likely originate?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, palpation of hard, irregular nodules within the prostate with immunohistochemistry revealing the absence of an outer basal layer is suggestive of carcinoma prostate and most prostatic carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common form of cancer affecting men. It arises in the peripheral zone of the gland, classically in a posterior location. 

The growth and survival of prostate cancer cells depend on androgens, which bind to the androgen receptor (AR) and induce the expression of pro-growth and pro-survival genes. Germline mutations of the tumor suppressor BRCA2 increase the risk of prostate cancer. Other acquired mutations include TPRSS2-ETS fusion genes. Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia(PIN) has been described as the precursor lesion of carcinoma prostate.

On palpation, it is gritty, and firm in consistency. Histologically, most lesions are adenocarcinomas that shows small crowded glands lined by a single layer of neoplastic cells with mild to moderate degree of pleomorphism. The outer basal cell layer is absent. Immunohistochemically, basal cell markers are absent and α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) positive.

Grading of prostate cancer by the modified Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.

Grade Group 1 (≤6)

 Only individual discrete well-formed glands

Grade Group 2 (3 + 4)

Predominantly well-formed glands with a lesser component of poorly formed, fused, or cribriform glands

Grade Group 3 (4 + 3)

 Predominantly poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands with a lesser component of well-formed glands

Grade Group 4 (4+4/3+5/5+3)

Only poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands or predominantly mix of well-formed glands and lack of glands

Grade Group 5 (4+5/5+4/5+5)

 Lack of gland formation (or with necrosis) with or without poorly formed/fused/cribriform glands

questions.text: Which of the following histologic findings would be most suggestive of Buerger’s disease in a patient?

choices.text: Mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasavasorum

questions.solution:
Luminal thrombosis containing small microabscesses composed of neutrophils is seen in thromboangiitis obliterans or Buerger disease.

Option A: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum has been described in Takayasu arteritis.

Option B: Fragmented neutrophils undergoing apoptosis infiltrating blood vessels termed leukocytoclastic vasculitis are seen in small vessel vasculitis.

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels seen in immunologically mediated vasculitis syndromes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a facial rash, arthralgia, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. She is found to have renal failure with poor urine output. Renal biopsy is performed, followed by staining with periodic acid Schiff; microscopic appearance is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is_______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical details and histopathology image are suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

In the image, glomerulus is hypercellular (endocapillary proliferation). Glomerular capillary loops appear circumferentially thickened, forming "wire loop" lesion, which is classically seen in Class IV or diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis.

Wire-loop lesions are formed due to subendothelial immune complex deposits, creating a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall.

Lupus nephritis:

Up to 50% of SLE patients have clinically significant renal involvement.

All renal compartments including glomerular, tubulointerstitial, and vascular components may be injured by the disease; however, the term “lupus nephritis” is mainly used to define the immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

Deposition of immune complexes is regularly present in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane and sometimes throughout the glomerulus.

According to the currently accepted classification, six patterns of glomerular disease are seen in SLE.

Class IV is the most common and most severe pattern, and Class I is the least common pattern.

Interesting facts:

The term "lupus" (means wolf in Latin) was first coined by thirteenth century physician Rogerius to describe facial lesions caused by the disease that looked like wolf bites.

Later in nineteenth century, Kaposi claimed that there were two forms of the disease—systemic lupus erythematosus and discoid lupus.

Further, autopsy studies documented the existence of nonbacterial verrucous endocarditis (Libman–Sacks disease) and wire-loop lesions in SLE patients with glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 
  • Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli
  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus
  • Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text: A 25 year old female presents with a neck swelling. Isotope scan of her thyroid gland shows a “cold” nodule. This nodule is removed and microscopy is as seen below. All are true about the tumour except:

choices.text: Follicular variant is the most common variant
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
Associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
The image shows papillary carcinoma of thyroid with papillae lined by cells with overlapping and clearing of nuclei and inclusions. Involvement of blood vessels by tumor cells is relatively uncommon but metastases to adjacent cervical lymph nodes occur in up to half of the cases.

  • Presents as painless nodule or mass in the neck or cervical node in women of reproductive age.
  • Usually cold nodule on a scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with fibrovascular stalk
  • Nuclear changes  - Optically clear -  Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves
  • Risk factors – Exposure to ionizing radiation, Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Diagnosis can be made based on these nuclear features, even in the absence of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies are often present
  • Most common variant of papillary carcinoma is the follicular variant
  • Tall cell variant – increased frequencies of vascular invasion, extrathyroidal extension, and cervical and distant metastases.
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%

questions.text: The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of:
questions.solution:
The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases.

There is no histologic feature that reliably predicts clinical behavior in phaeochromocytomas.

Numbers of mitoses, confluent tumor necrosis, cellular monotony, and spindle cell morphology - associated with an aggressive behavior and increased risk of metastasis, but are not entirely reliable.

Cellular and nuclear pleomorphism, presence of giant cells, mitotic figures, capsular and vascular invasion seen in benign pheochromocytomas.

The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases. These may involve regional lymph nodes, liver, lung, and bone.

questions.text: An example of CX3C chemokine is:
questions.solution:
The only known member of the CX3C chemokine class is called fractalkine.

Chemokines are a family of small proteins that act primarily as chemoattractants for specific types of leukocytes.

They are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins.

 

Chemokines Types Features and examples

neutrophils		 e.g.IL8 Cause activation &
chemotaxis of

other cytokines (Mainly IL-1 & TNF)

neutrophils		 MCP-1
(Monocyte chemoattractant protein)		 RANTES (regulated & normal 
T-cell expressed & secreted)		 Eotaxin (selectively recruits eosinophils)
γ-chemokines Relatively selective for lymphocytes e.g.Lymphotactin Attracts T cell precursor to thymus
CX3C chemokines Chemotactic for monocyte & T cell Fractalkine is the only known member of this class

questions.text: Precursor lesion of hepatocellular carcinoma:
questions.solution:
All of the above lesions are precursors to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Risk factors for HCC

  • HBV, HCV,aflatoxin, alcohol
  • Hereditary hemochromatosis, α1AT deficiency, Wilson disease, metabolic syndrome and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Precursors of HCC

  • Hepatocellular adenoma in particular those with β-catenin activating mutations
  • Small cell change
  • Large cell change
  • Low grade dysplastic nodule
  • High-grade dysplastic nodules

questions.text: A peripheral smear of a 40-year-old female with chronic anaemia and gall stones is as seen below. The patient develops a sudden worsening of anaemia requiring transfusion. What is the most likely Etiology?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows many spherocytes classically described in hereditary spherocytosis.

  • The generally stable clinical course of hereditary spherocytosis is sometimes punctuated by an aplastic crisis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection.
  • Parvovirus infects and kills red cell progenitors, effectively causing red cell production to cease until an immune response commences, generally in 1 to 2 weeks.
  • The reduced life span of HS red cells + cessation of erythropoiesis → leads to a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Transfusions may be necessary to support the patient until the immune response clears the infection

questions.text: A patient with severe emphysema underwent lung volume reduction surgery. The resected specimen is shown below. What type of emphysema is this?
questions.solution:
The given gross image is characteristic of centriacinar emphysema.

In paraseptal emphysema subpleural spaces are mainly affected (shown below).

In panacinar emphysema all air spaces within acini are evenly enlarged (shown below).

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: Histopathological images of the oesophageal biopsies are given below. What of the following adaptive mechanisms is observed in the epithelium?
questions.solution:
The image shows a replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus by metaplastic glandular epithelium containing intestinal-type goblet cells. The image on the left is Barrett's esophagus with non-dysplasia and on the right is Barrett's esophagus with low-grade dysplasia. The adaptive mechanism that is observed here is metaplasia.

Metaplasia is a reversible transformation where a differentiated cell type, either epithelial or mesenchymal, is replaced by another cell type. It serves as an adaptive reaction, where a cell type susceptible to specific stress is substituted by another cell type that can better endure unfavorable conditions. The most frequent form of epithelial metaplasia is the transition from columnar to squamous cells, which can be observed in the respiratory tract as a response to persistent irritation.

 

Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type. Represents an adaptive response in which one cell type that is sensitive to a particular stress is replaced by another cell type that is better able to withstand the adverse environment. Most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous as occurs in the respiratory tract in response to chronic irritation.

Epithelial

Squamous metaplasia

Transformation of different epithelium into stratified squamous epithelium.

- Bronchial mucosal pseudostratified columnar irritated by cigarette smoke

- Transitional epithelium of bladder irritated with bladder stones

- Epithelial lining of ducts of exocrine glands (salivary, pancreas) and bile ducts with canaliculi

- Endocervix

Columnar  -  Squamous cells to columnar cells

- Barrett’s esophagus

Connective tissue metaplasia

Formation of cartilage, bone, or adipose tissue (mesenchymal tissues) in tissues that normally do not contain these elements.

In myositis ossificans, occasionally occurs after intramuscular hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with slowly-progressive, painless loss of central vision. A detailed family history from this patient elicits the following pedigree chart where dark circles or squares indicate affected individuals. What is the mode of inheritance in the said disease?
questions.solution:
All progeny of an affected male are normal, but all children, male and female, of the affected female (shaded circles) manifest disease to a variable degree. The mode of inheritance depicted in the pedigree chart is maternal inheritance classically described in mitochondrial disorders.

  • Mitochondrial genes - Maternal inheritance.
  • mtDNA complement of the zygote is derived entirely from the ovum.
  • Mothers transmit mtDNA to all their offspring, male and female; however, daughters but not sons transmit the DNA further to their progeny.
  • mtDNA encodes enzymes involved in oxidative phosphorylation
  • Individuals may harbor both wildtype and mutant mtDNA, a situation called heteroplasmy.
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is a prototype of mitochondrial disorder.
  • Neurodegenerative disease that manifests as a progressive bilateral loss of central vision.
  • Cardiac conduction defects and minor neurologic manifestations have also been observed.

Classic mitochondrial syndromes

Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia
Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
Mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke
Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers
Mitochondrial myopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and gastrointestinal encephalopathy
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa
Kearns-Sayre syndrome

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain and melena. On endoscopy, a bleeding gastric mass with irregular borders was identified along the greater curvature of the stomach. Microscopy is as shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific marker for the tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological picture showing spindle-shaped tumor cells are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), for which CD 117 is the specific marker. 

GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, with the most common site being the stomach. The tumor arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.

Most GISTs occur due to gain-of-function mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase KIT (~75%) or PDGRF-ɑ (~8%). 

The tumor peaks at 60 years of age. It is often associated with the Carney triad, a nonhereditary condition characterized by GIST, paraganglioma, and pulmonary chondroma. GIST also has a higher incidence in individuals with neurofibromatosis I.

Patients typically present with anemia (due to blood loss caused by mucosal ulceration) and symptoms of mass effect. However, GISTs may also be discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery.

Microscopically, GIST can be of two patterns:

  1. Spindle cell type: The tumor is composed of thin elongated cells.
  2. Epitheloid type: The tumor is composed of plump epithelial-like cells.

Mixed patterns may also be seen.

The most useful immunohistochemical marker is KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells, along with DOG1.

The prognosis depends on tumor size, mitotic index, and location (GISTs arising in the stomach are less aggressive than those arising in the small intestine). Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used. 

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

Related Pearl: The most commons in GIT

Most common Structure/Conditions
Congenital intestinal atresia Imperforate anus
True diverticulum Meckel's diverticulum
Site of ischemia Colon
Site of fistulization Esophagus
Site of GI polyp Colorectum
Malignancy of GI tract Adenocarcinoma colon
Cause of esophagitis Acid reflux
Benign tumor of the esophagus Leiomyoma
Esophageal cancer in India and worldwide Squamous cell carcinoma
Esophageal cancer in Western countries Adenocarcinoma
Type of chronic gastritis Type B gastritis (Helicobacter pylori gastritis)
Malignancy of the stomach Adenocarcinoma
Site of extranodal lymphoma Stomach
Mesenchymal tumor of the stomach Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)
Tumor of small intestine/appendix Carcinoid

 

Related Pearl: Carney's complex, triad, and diad

Carney complex includes:

  • Myxomas - cardiac, skin, and/or breast
  • Lentigines and/or pigmented nevi
  • Endocrine overactivity - primary nodular adrenal cortical disease, testicular tumors, and/or pituitary adenomas with gigantism or acromegaly

 Carney's triad includes:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extraadrenal paraganglioma

Carney-Stratakis syndrome also called Carney's diad includes:

  • GIST
  • Paraganglioma

questions.text: The fixative routinely used in histopathology
questions.solution:
The most widely used fixative for routine histopathology is 10% neutral buffered formalin. This fixative can effectively prevent autolysis and provides excellent preservation of tissue and cellular morphology.

Other options:

  • Bouins fixative - Used for testicular biopsies, also as a mordant for staining procedures.
  • Glutaraldehyde- Fixative in electron microscopy. The standard solution is a 2% buffered glutaraldehyde.
  • Ethyl alcohol- Ideal fixative for cytological smears because they act quickly and give good nuclear detail.

questions.text: The characteristic inclusion in the cytoplasm of the cell seen below contains:
questions.solution:
The image shows a Mott Cell containing multiple immunoglobulin globules in grapelike cytoplasmic droplets. Mott Cells may be seen in African trypanosomiasis and in multiple myeloma.

Other options:

Option A: Viral inclusions containing replication proteins and virions may be seen in the case of HSV-infected cells. Intranuclear inclusions called Cowdry Type A bodies as shown below are seen. These bodies push the host cell chromatin to the edge of the nucleus.

Option D: Apoptotic cells break up into fragments called apoptotic bodies. These apoptotic bodies have intact plasma membranes but altered structures. Councilman bodies are a type of apoptotic body. They are acidophilic (eosinophilic) globule of cells that represents a dying hepatocyte often surrounded by normal parenchyma.

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: Histopathological examination of a lymph node is as seen below. Which of the following condition does this pathology represent?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a granuloma formed by epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleate giant cells and surrounded by lymphocytes. This is an example for Type IV or cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Type IV or cell mediated hypersensitivity reaction:

  • Seen with persistent or nondegradable antigens, such as tubercle bacilli in lungs or other tissues. Infiltrate is dominated by macrophages over a period of 2 or 3 weeks.
  • With sustained activation, macrophages often undergo a morphologic transformation into epithelioid cells (large epithelium-like cells with abundant cytoplasm).
  • A microscopic aggregation of epithelioid cells, usually surrounded by a collar of lymphocytes, is referred to as a granuloma.
  • This pattern of inflammation, called granulomatous inflammation is typically associated with strong TH1-cell activation and high-level production of cytokines such as IFN-γ.

questions.text: All the following tumours are correctly matched with their respective  immunohistochemical markers except
questions.solution:
• SMA is used to identify smooth muscle cells, myoepithelial cells and myofibroblasts in normal, reactive or neoplastic tissue.
  • It does not stain neoplasticcells in rhabdomyosarcoma which are of skeletal muscle origin.
  • Specific markers for cells of skeletal muscle origin are Desmin, Myo-D1 and Myogenin.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was transferred to the emergency room after a car accident. Twenty-four hours after admission, the patient manifested tachycardia, dyspnea, and hypoxemia. After the autopsy, the diagnosis of fat embolism was made. Which of the following special stains on autopsy was used for the microscopy of a cryostat section from the lung?
questions.solution:
The oil red O (ORO) stain can identify neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues. A frozen section must be done so that the tissue need not go through routine processing. Oil red O stains the lipid in the vacuoles in the pulmonary vasculature.

  • Fixatives containing alcohols, or routine tissue processing with clearing, will remove lipids.
  • ORO is a rapid and simple stain.
  • It can be useful in identifying fat emboli in lung tissue or clot sections of peripheral blood.

Uses:

  • Diagnose renal cell carcinoma, sebaceous gland tumors of the skin, lipid-rich carcinomas.
  • Identify fat emboli in lung tissue or clot sections of peripheral blood.

questions.text: Metastatic calcification is seen in
questions.solution:
• Metastatic calcification is seen in hypercalcemia and in otherwise normal tissue.
  • Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of fat necrosis, stenotic valves and atheromas.
  • Pathologic calcification is the abnormal tissue deposition of calcium salts, together with smaller amounts of iron, magnesium, and other mineral salts.

Two forms of pathologic calcification

Dystrophic calcification – In dead and degenerating tissues.

  • Normal serum levels of calcium
  • In areas of necrosis - coagulative, caseous, liquefactive type, and enzymatic necrosis of fat.
  • Atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis, aging or damaged heart valves, tuberculous lymph nodes, infarcts, thrombi, hematomas.

Metastatic calcification-  Deposition of calcium salts in otherwise normal tissues

  • Hypercalcemia secondary to some disturbance in calcium metabolism.
  • Principal causes of hypercalcemia:
    • Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH)
    • Resorption of bone tissue
    • Vitamin D–related disorders
    • Renal failure
    • Aluminum intoxication
    • Milk-alkali syndrome
  • Sites- Interstitial tissues of the gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins.

questions.text: An infant born to a diabetic mother develops difficulty in breathing within 30 minutes of birth. Within a few hours, cyanosis becomes evident. Fine rales are heard over both lung fields. A chest x-ray film shows ground-glass picture. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: It is associated with respiratory failure and poor prognosis despite treatment
There is deficiency of surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells
Increased corticosteroid release lower the risk of developing RDS
On microscopy, hyaline membranes with fibrin and necrotic cell debris are seen

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is characteristic of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyaline membrane disease. With treatment, it rarely leads to respiratory failure and has a good prognosis. 

The fundamental defect is a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, produced by type II pneumocytes. 

Microscopically, the hyaline membranes are largely made up of fibrin admixed with necrotic cell debris. Grossly, the lungs are of normal size, solid, airless, reddish-purple, and they usually sink in water.

Corticosteroids help in surfactant production and are given prophylactically to at-risk pregnant women.

Related Pearl: Pulmonary surfactant

It lowers the surface tension of the water layer at the alveolar surface, which increases lung compliance, thereby making it easier for the lungs to expand. It is secreted by type II alveolar cells. It is a mixture of phospholipids and protein.

4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant proteins are (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

  • SP-A - Regulation of the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveolar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B & SP-C - Key protein members of the monomolecular film of surfactant.
  • SP-D - Organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

A deep breath increases its secretion by stretching the type II cells. Its concentration decreases when breaths are small.

In the fetus, surfactant synthesis is variable. The surfactant may be present as early as gestational week 24 and is almost always present by gestational week 35.

questions.text: The purpose of the Ames test could be to study a compound’s
questions.solution:
• The Ames test is a widely employed method that uses bacteria to test whether a given chemical can cause mutations in the DNA of the test organism.
  • More formally, it is a biological assay to assess the mutagenic potential of chemical compounds.
  • A positive test indicates that the chemical is mutagenic and therefore may act as a carcinogen, because cancer is often linked to mutation.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to stain calcium in tissue sections?
questions.solution:
The special stains used for calcium in tissue sections are von Kossa and Alizarin Red.

Best method to demonstrate mineralization of bone: Tetracycline-labelling index.

questions.text: The phenomenon in which the rapidly growing cells upregulate glucose and glutamine uptake and decrease their production of ATP per glucose molecule is called ________
questions.solution:
Warburg effect

  • Pure oxidative phosphorylation produces abundant adenosine triphosphate ATP, but also “burns” glucose to CO2 and H2O, leaving no carbon moieties suitable for use as building blocks for lipids or proteins.
  • For this reason, rapidly growing cells (both benign and malignant) upregulate glucose and glutamine uptake and decrease their production of ATP per glucose molecule, a phenomenon called the Warburg effect.

Other options:

  • Option a: Crabtree effect: It is a phenomenon whereby yeast species, such as Saccharomyces cerevisiae, produce ethanol (alcohol) in aerobic conditions and high external glucose concentrations, rather than producing biomass via the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle.
  • Option c: Pasteur effect: It refers to the effect first discovered by Louis Pasteur, wherein aerating yeasted broth causes an increase in yeast cell growth, while conversely decreasing the fermentation rate. The effect occurs due to the difference in the efficiency of energy production by the anaerobic and aerobic pathways (citric acid cycle).
  • Option d: Haldane effect: It is a property of hemoglobin, where oxygenation of blood in the lungs displaces carbon dioxide from hemoglobin, thereby increasing the removal of carbon dioxide.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen in the spleen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen.

An infarct is a region of ischaemic necrosis resulting from the obstruction of blood flow, typically due to occlusion of the arterial supply or venous drainage. The most common cause of solid organ infarts is thromboembolism.

The pattern of ischemic necrosis seen in solid organ infarction is coagulative necrosis. However, CNS infarctions are an exception. They cause liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: Who discovered the process of phagocytosis?
questions.solution:
Ilya Ilyich Mechnikov discovered the process of phagocytosis. He is known as the father of natural immunity and established the concept of cell-mediated immunity.

He was jointly awarded the 1908 Nobel Prize in Physiology along with Paul Ehrlich, who established the concept of humoral immunity.

questions.text: What mutation causes the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis?
questions.solution: Tay–Sachs disease, the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis, results from mutations in the α-subunit locus on chromosome 15 that causes a severe deficiency of hexosaminidase A.

questions.text: A newborn baby born at term was noted to have respiratory distress. Radiography revealed diffuse ground-glass opacities in all lung fields. Exogenous surfactant administration resulted in a brief improvement, but his condition continued to worsen once surfactant therapy was stopped. Which is the most common genetic mutation associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of surfactant dysfunction disorder. It is most commonly caused by mutations of ABCA3 gene.

In this disorder, lack of production of surfactant leads to severe respiratory failure in neonates. There is transient improvement with administration of exogenous surfactant, but it worsens once surfactant therapy is stopped. This condition occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in surfactant trafficking or secretion such as:

  • ATP binding cassette protein member 3 (ABCA3) 
  • Surfactant protein C
  • Surfactant protein B

Related Pearl: Pulmonary surfactant

It lowers the surface tension of the water layer at the alveolar surface, which increases lung compliance, thereby making it easier for the lungs to expand. It is secreted by type II alveolar cells. It is a mixture of phospholipids and protein.

4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant proteins are (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

  • SP-A - Regulation of the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveolar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B & SP-C - Key protein members of the monomolecular film of surfactant.
  • SP-D - Organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

A deep breath increases its secretion by stretching the type II cells. Its concentration decreases when breaths are small.

In the fetus, surfactant synthesis is variable. The surfactant may be present as early as gestational week 24 and is almost always present by gestational week 35.

questions.text: A biopsy was performed on a female patient who presented with a lump in her right breast. Presence of which of the following findings is not associated with an increased risk of cancer?
questions.solution:
Apocrine change does not increase the risk of cancer as it is a non-proliferative change.

Moderate or florid hyperplasia, fibroadenoma with complex features, and sclerosing adenosis are classified under proliferative disease without atypia with a 1.5- to 2-fold increased risk of carcinoma.

Both breasts are at increased risk, although the risk to the ipsilateral breast may be slightly higher.

Related Pearl: Epithelial Lesions and Risk of Malignancy

Pathologic Lesions and Relative Risk of Malignancy

Examples 

Non-proliferative Breast Changes / Fibrocystic changes

(RR = 1)
  • Duct ectasia
  • Cysts
  • Apocrine change
  • Mild hyperplasia
  • Adenosis
  • Fibroadenoma without complex features

Proliferative Disease Without Atypia

(RR = 1.5 to 2)
  • Moderate or florid hyperplasia
  • Sclerosing adenosis
  • Papilloma
  • Complex sclerosing lesion (radial scar)
  • Fibroadenoma with complex features

Proliferative Disease with Atypia

(RR = 4 to 5)
  • Atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH)
  • Atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH)

Carcinoma in situ

(RR = 8 to 10)
  • Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)
  • Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

questions.text: Patients with sickle cell disease are particularly susceptible to osteomyelitis caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Salmonella enteritidis is commonly implicated in osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia.

The common causative organisms include:
  • Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers
  • Salmonella - most common in patients of sickle cell anemia
  • Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due to vaccination
  • Streptococcus pyogenes - neonates
  • Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presents with fever and jaundice for 5 days. On examination, splenomegaly is noted. Her lab reports are given below. What is the likely trigger to have caused this condition?

Hb - 5 g%

WBC - 1000 /mm3

Platelets - 45,000 /mm3

Peripheral smear shows spherocytes
questions.solution:
The given hemogram showing pancytopenia and spherocytes in peripheral smear is suggestive of aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis. It is usually triggered by parvovirus infection.

Parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This creates a transient arrest of erythropoiesis i.e. aplastic crisis as the life span of RBCs are shortened. The immune response clears the virus in 1-2 weeks.

Blood transfusions may be necessary during acute phases of the infection. This crisis can also occur in other hemolytic anaemias.

questions.text: Which cytokine is an important growth factor for plasma cells in multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
The proliferation and survival of plasma cells are dependent on several cytokines, most notably IL-6.

It is an important growth factor for plasma cells. It is produced by the tumor cells themselves and by resident marrow stromal cells. IL6, along with other cytokines, promotes osteoclastic activity and lytic bone lesions. High serum levels of IL-6 are seen in patients with active disease and are associated with a poor prognosis.
